I assume it would depend on the town's ordinances and state statutes, but here in OK there are a number of managers who work for a municipality and never receive a contract.

answers.author: William Gilmore
answers.text:
Create a consulting contract, one page that refers to his/her pending formal contract and job description for the position, that he/she will serve in an interim role till the formal contract is put in place.  Set aside a retainer that could be drawn against for invoices from the interim contractor.  The hourly rate would be set at an agreed amount of no more than would qualify for the pending negotiated salary and benefits.  Also consider putting language in the contract that there is no guarantee of formal hire in case you learn that the individual does not meet your performance expectations.  
I also agree with David, a formal contract is not required but generally is preferred since Managers can be terminated at a moments notice without cause in an "at will" state.

answers.author: Kenneth Decker
answers.text:
The short answer is, "Yes."  While most of us would prefer a contract, there are times when this isn't possible.  In my last position, I didn't sign a contract until I had worked for two years.  As with many job-related decisions, to work without a contract is a calculated risk.  Good luck.
